prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: CN is strong in NGC253, the on-source measurements can be carried out in almost no time. The requested array is compact and the lowest frequency band will be used, which does not require exceptional whether conditions.

The 13CN peak flux is 50mJy within a 22 arcsec beam. For 50 square arcseconds extent and a 3.4 arcsec beam, there will be an average of 5 independent pixels with about 10 mJy each. A 1 mJy is thus appropriate to also get sufficient signal to noise to determine a CN/13CN ratio. In principle, 10 contiguous channels could be smoothed to reach a 3 times lower signal-to-noise ratio per channel than that given here.Compact configuration, band 3, one pointing.

CN is strong in NGC1068, the on-source measurements can be carried out in almost no time. The requested array is compact and the lowest frequency band will be used, which does not require exceptional whether conditions.

The 13CN peak flux of 10mJy within a 22 arcsec beam originates mostly from the very center and should be easily detected. Possibly also detectable are peaks in the starburst ring. In principle, 10 channels could be smoothed to reach a 3 times lower signal-to-noise ratio per channel than that given here. Band 3, compact array, single pointing.

CN is strong in NGC4945, the on-source measurements can be carried out in almost no time. The requested array is compact and the lowest frequency band will be used, which does not require exceptional whether conditions.

Perhaps the strongest 13CN source, because of particularly strong CN. However, this depends on the unknown 12C/13C ratio. In principle, 10 channels could be smoothed to reach a 3 times lower signal-to-noise ratio per channel than that given here. Band 3, one position, compact array.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: To trace the chemical evolution of galaxies, a detailed knowledge of abundance patterns is fundamental. Isotope ratios play a key role in such studies and are, almost exclusively, a domain of radio and (sub-)mm astronomy. So far, the extragalactic space beyond the Magellanic Clouds is almost unexplored. What ratios can be found, when observing objects beyond the Local Group, which drastically differ from those in the Miliky Way and the LMC? Is the Galaxy typical for its class or are its isotopic properties exceptional? And what does this imply for its evolutionary track? Such questions can only be tackled when using the extreme sensitivity of ALMA. Here we propose to measure carbon (and oxygeni) isotope ratios in three outstanding star forming galaxies beyond the Local Group.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00912.S - The Origin of 15N: Synthesis in High or Low Mass Stars? Cycle 1 - went very well. HC15N is clearly detected. HCN/HC15N ~ 200 in NGC4945. Being presently written up. It is not yet entirely clear, whether the data will be published in one or two papers (based on a total of 33 minutes on-source time!). In addition to 15N, there are quite a number of other interesting items and some surprises, like the presence of absorption lines.
